texts:
By late morning mother and Kita were visiting the drugstore.  Mother explained the problem.  The man behind the counter was kind as he ex- plained about head lice.

     He told them that not only is head lice annoy- ing, but it is also contagious.  The tiny insects feed off of very small drops of blood drawn from the scalp.  The bites cause itching.  Scratching them can lead to infection.

Lice are often passed from one person to another by close contact, by sharing hats or scarves, or by using someone else's towel.

     The man at the drug store gave Kita's mother some medicated shampoo.  It may be necessary to use the shampoo again in 5 - 10 days.

After shampooing, Kita's mother parted her hair into small sections and checked her hair with a fine-toothed comb.  She removed all the little eggs (nits) that were clinging tightly to Kita's hair.
(If hair is tightly curled, it may not be possible to do this step.)     She checked Kita's brother's head, too.  Then she carefully washed their hats, scarves, combs, and brushes.
     She also washed the blankets and pillows that were on their beds.

Kita's mother hung the clothes and bedding in the sun.  She also let the combs and brushes dry in the warm sun.

     After 10 days, she checked the children's hair again to be sure that there were no new eggs or lice.

texts:
Fannie Moore  1849 – 1937   
Born a plantation slave in South Carolina, USA.
Adapted from an interview with Fannie when she was an old woman.Master Jim Moore  he own the biggest plantation in the whole country. One side of the river stood the big house, where the white folks lived. Painted white with lots of rooms. We lived the other side of the river in a row of dirt cabins, one room for each family.

Old Mrs. Moore She say slaves didn’t need nothing to eat. They just like animals, not like other folks. She whip me many time with a cow whip.  
Master Jim’s wife She was the sweetest woman I ever saw. She was always good to every slave.My granny cooked corn bread with milk for us children and looked after us while my mama worked.My mama she work in the field all day and then had to sew for the white folks all night. Some nights I never went to bed because I had to hold the light for her to see by. I could never see how she could stand such hard work. She had twelve children.

My pappy was a blacksmith, shoeing all the horses on the plantation. He was sold to the Moores with his mama, she was brought over from Africa. She never could speak English plain. All her life she had been a slave.Sometimes a tradesman would come to the plantation to buy a slave. Everyone was frightened that they would be taken away and sold to a new, bad owner. None of us slaves had any learning, we were not allowed to learn to read or write, or go to church. The white folks were afraid we would get too smart and be difficult to manage.

When I was 12 my pappy went off with the Master to fight in the Civil War. My pappy go to do the Master’s cooking. My pappy say some days he run four or five miles before he could stop to cook with the bullets falling all around the pots.After the war Pappy go back to work on the plantation. Now he was no longer a slave but a worker, and could grow some of his own crops. He sure was happy that he was free. Mama she shout for joy.

But even in the face of uncertainty, life persisted. A small sprout pushed its way through the earth, a testament to the resilience of nature and the promise of a new beginning.

texts: Why do we tell about the Holy Spirit along with the Christmas story? Because the Holy Spirit is mentioned in the Gospel of Luke beginning with the parents of John the Baptist, Zechariah and Elizabeth. An angel told Zechariah about his son John, “He will be filled with the Holy Spirit even from birth.” And we are told about Elizabeth, that she “was filled with the Holy Spirit.” Again we learn that Zechariah “was filled with the Holy Spirit,” singing a song of joy. When John was born “the child grew and became strong in spirit.”An angel came to Mary, the mother of Jesus, and told her, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High. So the holy one to be born will be called the Son of God.”

We read of old Simeon, who once held the Baby Jesus, “The Holy Spirit was upon him (Simeon). It had been told to him by the Holy Spirit ... that he would not die before he had seen the Lord Christ ... moved by the Spirit he went into the temple courts...” where he met Joseph, Mary, and the baby Jesus. At the same time elderly Anna, a woman of much prayer, saw baby Jesus and knew by the Spirit that Jesus was the promised Savior. She spoke everywhere that the Savior had come. (Luke 2)

There are many other sayings about the Holy Spirit and Jesus such as, “He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit... the Holy Spirit came down upon Him, looking like a dove ... Jesus, full of the Spirit, was led by the Spirit into the desert... Jesus returned to Galilee in the power of the Spirit...”

When Jesus read out loud from the Book of Isaiah 61:1, 2, “The Spirit of the Lord is upon Me, because He has anointed Me to preach good news,” Jesus said that the 700-year-old verses from Isaiah came true that day, in Him, Jesus.And He told His disciples, “the Holy Spirit will teach you what you should say... I am going to send what My Father has promised (the Holy Spirit), but stay in the city until you have been given power from on high.” This was to show them and us what a great gift the Holy Spirit is. The Holy Spirit is a lasting gift so that we may tell others about God.

After the Lord Jesus left them and returned to Heaven, His followers prayed and waited. Then 40 days later, the Holy Spirit came to live in them (and in us!) They had great joy and the ability to speak in many different languages to the people around them. Three thousand new followers believed in Jesus, and were baptized that great day.

This gift of the Holy Spirit continues to spread the joys of the birth of Christ all over the world. We can have the joy of Christmas all year round with God’s Spirit in our hearts.

The apostle Paul wrote a letter to the people in Galatia. It said, “Live by the Spirit ... if you are led by the Spirit ... the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control ... let us keep in step with the Spirit.” (Gal. 4) Paul also told how the Holy Spirit gives us spiritual gifts so we can help others.Paul wrote, “There are different kinds of gifts, but the same Spirit. There are different kinds of service, but the same Lord. There are different kinds of working but the same God works in all of them ... now to each person the Spirit is given for the good of all.” (I Cor. 12) The good of all! The blessing of all!

Now God had decided to save His people, the Hebrews, and take them away from the land of Egypt. He gave Moses careful orders as to how the Hebrews should get ready, and then told him what night they should leave.

To make the ruler of Egypt willing to let the Hebrews leave, God knew that He would have to punish all the Egyptians in a way they had never been punished before and never would be so punished again. He said to Moses, “I will send the Angel of Death to kill all the oldest sons of the Egyptians, but I will save all the oldest sons of you, my people. But you must, family by family, kill a lamb and place some of its blood on the top and sides of your front doors.

Now God had told Moses, “When My people are ready to leave, they should visit their Egyptian neighbors and ask for help for their journey. They will find that the Egyptians are willing to give them supplies and other gifts.” When on the Passover night the Hebrews started to go to see their Egyptian neighbors, someone said, “What about their dogs?” and quickly another replied, “They won’t bark at us; remember what Moses heard from the Lord God.”And when they went to the homes of Egyptians, where ordinarily the watchdogs would have barked at them, even the Egyptian dogs were silent. God kept them from barking, so that the Egyptians would know even more certainly that the God of the Hebrews controlled even the animals.

texts:
We had found the round blue stone in the cave when we were playing the day before. We were told that it belongs to our ancestors.
All was silent except for the night owl cooing from a nearby tree. I made a quick sign of the cross on my forehead and chest with lime to ward off the spirits. Bilbil’s voice shook as he said, “I'm scared, Regat."
“Did you rub the ginger on your body like I said.”
"No!" said Bilbil.
“Well it's too late now. Come on."
The distance from the house to the cave seemed endless. We felt our way with our bare feet and hands. “Rookee! Rookee!“
“What was that?“ asked Bilbil.

"Only a bat."
"Rookee! Rookee!" came the sharp shrieking sound again.
"Regat, I think it's a howling dog." 
I could feel cold tingles running down my spine. I was sweating and shaking all over.
The sound came closer and closer. My heart was pounding like the manus garamut. I remembered the lime pot Grandpa gave me. Carefully, I put some on my forehead and some on Bilbil.

Now we were at the cave entrance. As if angered by the ceremonial decoration, the shrieking cry came again, right in front of us.
"Who is here!" I kicked forward.
Bilbil lost his balance and fell. There was rustling scampering sound. Mice? Rats?
"Yuck! Yucky things!" said Bilbil, huffing and puffing from his fall.
Suddenly, I felt hands on my neck. I shouted, “Iesu, someone is strangling me!” I gasped for air.
“One, two, three,” both Bilbil and I shouted. “Out with the magic marble!”

We placed it on the ground. A strange aroma filled the cave. The noise grew louder and louder. There were running feet, flapping wings, howling, and human voices.
“One, two, three, run," we shouted. Then suddenly we stood face to face with To Lagulagu, the great spirit. He spoke to us in a language of old.
My children, the marble is yours. As you have proven yourself strong, you may keep it," he said. “You have broken through all the obstacles," he continued. “Wherever you are in danger, the magic marble will be your charm. May it ward off all enemies."
When I woke up, I could hardly believe what had happened. I opened my palm and there was the magic marble. It had been given to me by the great spirits of our ancestors. I could only smile and say, “I am truly a child of my forefathers."

texts:
What to do:

1) Heat the stones in a fire. Get them good and hot.
2) Cook the bananas on the fire.
3) While the stones are heating, scrape the coconuts.
4) Wash the aibika (greens) and chop the other vegetables.
5) Lay the banana leaves in a hollow made from the coconut husks (so that the coconut milk won't spill).

6) Put the aibika onto the banana leaves. Squeeze coconut milk over the aibika.
7) Squeeze the aibika gently so that there is a pool of coconut milk in the hollow of the banana leaves. Move the aibika to the side.
8) It is important to work quickly at this stage. Using tongs, take six hot stones from the fire. Rinse them quickly in water, and wrap them in bubu leaves. (This is to stop them from burning the food.)

9) Put the hot stones in the coconut milk. Put a piece of banana leaf over the stones.

10) Place the chicken on top of the banana leaf.

11) Squeeze more coconut milk over the chicken.

12) Add the rest of the vegetables.

13) Add another four rinsed wrapped hot stones.

14) Quickly wrap everything in the banana leaves. It is important to do this fast, before too much steam escapes.

15) Tie the bundle tightly.

16) Wait for fifteen minutes. Meanwhile, peel the cooked bananas.

17) Open the parcel and serve  

18) And Eat.

The ingredients are layered carefully, with hot stones providing the cooking heat. Banana leaves are used to wrap the food, trapping the steam and infusing the flavors.
The friend continues to squeeze water from the leaves, making sure that all of the essence is extracted for their delicious meal.
Finally, the community gathers around, eager to partake in the feast. Hands reach in to sample the results of their shared effort, a testament to tradition and togetherness.

texts:
When Amahl grew bigger, he could not find any work. I had to work for our money myself. I worked in town. But I know I could never buy all the things that Amahl needed. I knew he could never walk without help.

But Amahl was always happy. He sang. He made crutches for himself, so they could help him walk more easily. He made small birds and animals from wood. Sometimes I was able to sell them in the market.

Amahl often sat by the window and looked out over the hills. He dreamed about being a rich man, or a person who could make beautiful things. Sometimes this made me angry. I worked hard -- and he only made fine pictures in his head.

One day, when he was about nine years old, he said, “Look! Look at that bright star! It is too big. It is like white fire!”

I was cooking. I tried not to be angry. But I said, “You always think about things that are not true! What kind of star is there?”

Amahl said, “It is beautiful! I see it! I am not lying or dreaming!”

Later, we were all alone. We ate our supper as we always did, without talking much. That evening was like so many other evenings, until we were ready to sleep. Then someone knocked at our door. I was very tired. I thought, “If I wait, maybe the people will go away.” But they did not go away. They kept on knocking. After some time, I went to the door.

Three men were there. They were strangers. They wore long robes. I could see many kinds of cloth, and many colors. They wore jewelry, too. I didn’t know what jewelry was at that time. But jewelry is metal and shining stones, put together for a person to wear.

Then he did nothing at all. He just stood and looked down at me. At last I told him, “I know I was doing wrong. But you people have so much money, and I only wanted to help my boy. If we do not find more money soon, he will have to beg everyone for his food. He can’t work.”

I gave the money back. Everyone else woke up, but the short man still did not do anything. Then he said, “I hear what you have said. Take the gold. Take it for your child. The baby does not really need it.”

I just looked at him. Why were the kings carrying these loads so far, then, if the child did not need them? I could not understand.

Before I could do anything, Amahl had stood up with his crutches. Suddenly I could see that the crutches were not holding him. He was holding the crutches!

Then he dropped the crutches, and started to walk. In a minute, he picked them up again.

I jumped to catch him. I was afraid he would fall. But he just gave the crutches to the three kings.

I could not believe it. Amahl was walking! He said, “Look! I can walk! I am well!”

Francesca Drapuluvik,

Oni dipped a cloth in cool water and layed it over the burn.  When the cloth got warm she exchanged it for another.  She kept cooling the area for at least ten minutes.

Amadi will reapply the aloe vera, or apply an antibiotic cream, and cover the area two or three times a day until her leg is healed.  Her friend also gave her some ibuprofen to relieve the pain.        Oni assured her friend that she would check on her every day to make sure the wound is healing, and that there are no signs of infection.
     "If the area is not better in a week, we will have the doctor take a look at it," she said.  "I am glad the burned area is no larger than seven or eight centimeters, or we would have to seek medical help  right away."
Finally, Oni made sure Amadi had plenty of clean water or juice to drink.  Keeping hydrated is essential for healing.

"We will not make any noise or play in the sitting room again," they promise. 

"That is all right but maybe you need to go to the cell to think about what you have done," replies the commander. "Take them to the cell and lock them up," he tells me.

I march the troublemakers off to their cell. I push them both in and shut the door.

"I have a powerful policewomen, so keep yourselves out of trouble," warns the commander in a loud voice.

8:00pm. My commander and I go to his office for a cup of tea.  
"Well done officer," he says to me.

texts:
It was raining heavily. A hunter was carrying his dog on his shoulder.
“Poor dog,” he said. “Why did you hurt your leg?”
Suddenly an owl hooted. The dog was very frightened and jumped down. The hunter fell and the dog ran away. The hunter was very angry. He had a long way to go to his village. Then he found a nearby cave. The cave was very dark inside.
I'll wait here,” he said. “The dog can’t go far with one leg hurt.”
Soon he heard something move. It came towards him and touched him.

“Oh! It’s my dog!” he said. He picked it up and set off for home. “Stop struggling, you stupid dog, or I’ll break another leg!” he said. He tied it outside his house and went to sleep.  The next morning the hunter found a wild pig tied to the tree. He was very surprised.
“Did I carry a wild pig? I thought I carried my dog,” he said, staring.
Everyone heard the story, “He carried a wild pig,” they all said. “What a brave man!”
The hunter was very proud.

A few days later, there was a fight with their enemies.  “You are the bravest man,” the village chief said to the hunter. “You can even carry wild pigs. You must save us now.”
The hunter waited until it was dark. Then he crept along a steep hillside above where the enemy clan was camped. He was very scared. Suddenly he tripped on a stone. It rolled down the hill. Other stones began to roll and bounce down the hill into the enemy camp.

The enemy tribesmen woke to hear thundering stones tumbling down the hill at them. “We are being attacked!” they cried. They ran back to their village as fast as they could.
The hunter went back to the chief. “The enemies have gone,” he said. “I chased them back to their own village.”
“What a brave man! First he carried a wild pig. Now he has chased our enemies away.” And they feasted, and praised the hunter.
The next day the village chief came to see the hunter again.
“We have another problem ...” he said.
predicted_texts: A hunter returned to his village carrying a wolf he had hunted over his shoulder. He also carried a bow and arrow, ready for the next hunt.

The hunter proudly presented his prize, a captured wild boar, to the village. The villagers gathered around, their faces a mix of awe and anticipation, as the hunter demonstrated the strength and skill required to capture such a formidable beast.
The hunter was suddenly caught off guard by a large stone. He was picking it up off the ground when the stone began to violently shake in his hands.

The shaking stone became a catapult, launching other stones at the village! The villagers, once celebrating, scattered in terror as the stones rained down upon them. The hunter's prize became a source of unexpected chaos.

texts:
It was a bright Saturday morning. The sea was calm and peaceful. There was no school, so Rachel, Loloki, Rokana and I decided to go out to the sea to watch the moons. We got our coconut baskets and shells and made our way down to the beach. We scooped white sand into our coconut baskets and put them in the outrigger canoe. Then we paddled out to sea. As we went through the passage in the reef we got excited. We kept paddling until we came to a deep place.
"This is a good place to make our moons," Rokana suggested.
We filled our coconut shells with sand and held them over the side of the canoe opposite the outrigger. Then we poured them gently into the water. We watched with excitement as the moons of sand made their way down slowly to the deep.
Loloki called out, "Hey! Let's have a race to see whose moon can go down the fastest.

"Yes! A good idea." We all agreed.
"Make sure your shell is full with sand. I'll count to three." Loloki instructed.  "Are you all ready? One, two, three!"
We all poured our sand into the sea. We cheered as our moons travelled down through the dark blue water.
"My moon is travelling faster than yours," shouted Loloki.
"Mine has gone way down," I said.
The other girls cheered as our moons raced each other down into the sea. As we tried to get a last glimpse of them, we bent so far over the side of the canoe that our faces almost touched the water.
We didn't see the outrigger starting to lift. "Oh No!" We all screamed as we were tipped into the water.
When we came up, we saw the canoe drifting upside down. We panicked and pulled ourselves up onto the bank of the canoe.

"Aaiaaa! Mama. I want to go home," cried Loloki.
"We can't! The tide is taking us further out ot sea!" cried Rokana.
The further the canoe went, the louder Loloki and Rokana cried.
"There is nothing wrong with the canoe," I shouted. "Loloki and Rokana, stop crying! We can turn the canoe over."
"I am scared! A shark will eat me," cried Loloki.
"Mama!" Rokana screamed.
"Hey! If you don't get in the water and help me turn the canoe over, we'll be taken right out to sea, then we will be eaten by sharks. Now come on let's get to work."
Loloki, Rokana and Rachel slid slowly into the water.
"Rachel and Loloki, you will lift the outrigger. Rokana, you and I will be on the other side. As soon as the outrigger comes up, we'll pull the canoe towards us."
I commanded, "One, two, three!"
Loloki and Rachel lifted the outrigger, but the canoe moved away from them and the outrigger went splashing back into the water.

"Let's try again," I said. "Rokana, when Loloki and Rachel lift the outrigger, you and I will hold the ends and roll the canoe over." I swam around to the front of the canoe and Rokana swam to the back. "One, two, three!" I yelled.
Again the girls lifted the outrigger. Rokana and I twisted the ends. Slowly the outrigger went up, up, up, then over!
"Hurray! Hurray!" we cheered.
We got rid of the water, got into the canoe and paddled home leaving our moons of sand to rest in peace on the sea floor.

texts:
Scene: A house and the nearby bush.
Mama: Bauta, Kaumu, Walar. I'm going to the garden. Please stay in the house. There are many rascal activities going on around us. Bauta, please look after your little brother and sister. And be good, won't you.
Bauta: And Mama, I am in charge?
Mama: Yes, Bauta. Since you are bigger.
Kaumu & Walar: We will be good, Mama.

Mama goes off to the garden.Bauta: Kaumu, Walar, I'll just go quickly and get us some sugar cane. We will pass the time chewing while waiting for Mama. You stay inside the house till I return, OK?
Kaumu & Walar: OK
Bauta goes out. Kaumu and Walar play around for a while.
Kaumu: Bauta is not back yet. I'm already tired of staying inside the house now. Let's go out.
Walar: What about the raskols? You heard what Mama said.
Kaumu: It will be all right. We won't go far.
Walar: All right. But for a short time only.
The children open the door and run to the back of the house.
Kaumu: Walar! Come! See!

Walar: A laulau. A flying fox must have dropped it last night.
Kaumu: Let's find the tree. Come on. It must be around here.
He pulls Walar's hand.
Walar: I... I am scared.
Kaumu: Scared of what? We will just quickly find the laulau tree, get some fruits and get back into the house.
Walar: OK, but we'd better get back before Bauta returns.
The children run here and there looking for the tree. They search for some time.
Kaumu: Bingo! Here it is. I have found it. The laulau tree.
Walar: And look! There are plenty of ripe fruits on it.
Kaumu: I will throw this stone. You get ready to run and pick up any fruits that fall, OK?
Walar: OK

Kaumu: Are you ready?
Walar: Ready.
Kaumu takes aim and throws the stones. Many fruits fall. Walar runs and collects them. They sit down to eat.
Kaumu: Mmmm. They are the juiciest laulaus I have ever tasted.
Walar: And they are sweet, too. Unfortunately, Bautu is not here to enjoy these laulaus.

Bauta returns with the sugar cane only to find that Kaumu and Walar aren ’t at home. He hears them talking and goes in their direction.

Bauta: I will JUST creep up slowly from behind.
Walar: I am scared. You remember what Mama said.
Kaumu: OK! Put these laulaus in your pocket. We'd better go.

Bauta creeps up behind a tree. He sees the children and laughs softly.

Bauta: This time I am going to teach you a lesson.
Kaumu: Come on Walar. Let's get going.
Bauta: (from behind the tree): Hands up, you two. Now, do not look back. Keep your hands up and start walking.

Walar: What will we do?
Kaumu: I don't know. JUST obey.
Bauta: Hey! Stop whispering or I will blow your heads off.
Walar: I want to go home to Mama.
Kaumu: Shut up. It's one of those rascals Mama told us about. And maybe he has a gun.
Bauta: OK, you two. Run and touch that coconut tree. Then turn around and face me.
Walar: Come on Kaumu. Just do it.
Bauta: Ha ha ha! You look so funny!
Walar: Oh, Bautu. We were scared to death.
Kaumu: We thought you were a raskol.
Bauta: Well, next time never wander without my permission.
Kaumu: We are sorry.
Bauta: Now let's go home before Mama gets back.

texts:
One man went home and told his wife about it. His name was Jim. They were excited. They got a pot, some soil and some compost. They planted their seed and watched it every day. But nothing happened. After three weeks, some of the other men began to talk about the plants they had. Jim had nothing.

After six weeks Jim still had nothing but a pot. He put in a little water and fertilizer every day. He waited.

Six months passed. Jim decided that he had killed his seed somehow. There was no sign of life. The other men had trees and beautiful plants. He told them nothing about his pot because he was ashamed. The pot was still empty.

Six months after that, the big meeting came. Jim didn’t want to take his empty pot there. He felt a bit sick. His wife said, “Be honest. Take your pot and go.”

Jim did. He sat in a comer. The other men had beautiful plants. Some of them laughed at Jim’s empty pot. Others felt sorry for him.

The leader came in and saw all the plants. Then he found Jim and called him to the front of the room. Jim was very frightened. “I haven’t done anything,” he thought. “I’ll lose my job.” But he told his boss just what had happened.The other men said, “Jim has an empty pot. He won’t make our company grow either. How can he be our big man? Our company will fail.”

“A year ago,” the leader said, “I gave seeds to everybody. But I had boiled them first. There was no way they could grow. The seeds were dead.”

“I gave a seed to each of you. After a while,” he said, “you saw that nothing was going to grow. So you went out and bought other seeds to plant. You wanted to fool me.”

“Jim didn’t hide anything. He simply showed me what he had. He was the one with courage. He was honest. Jim is the new leader of our company.”

                                   *  *  *  *  *  *


“Do not be fooled. You cannot fool God. A man will get back whatever he plants.”
(Galatians 6:7, New Life New Testament)

                        ‘Friend, lend me three loaves of bread, because a friend of mine has stopped here while on a journey, and I have nothing to set before him.’

Then he will reply from inside, ‘Do not bother me. The door is already shut, and my children and I are in
                        bed. I cannot get up and give you anything.’

I tell you, even though the man inside will not get up and give him anything because he is his friend,

“So I tell you: Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and the door will be opened for you.

texts:
Dorah: OK! girls, let's go. Come here, Lillian. Dad said you have to work with us.

Lillian (coming out of the house): I'm sick of going to the garden. Do I have to come?

Dorah: Of course. We all have to work together.

They all walk to the garden.

Julie: Helen and Lillian, you two collect the vegetables.

Lillian (turning away): Ah, me again. It's always me.

Dorah: You help out. If you don't, we'll tell Dad.

The two girls sneak off into the bush.

Helen: When we get home Dad will get onto us.

Lillian (cutting a wild banana and peering through the vines): He always does anyway... Wow! Helen! Helen!

Helen: Coming!

Lillian: Quick! Quick! Bring a stick. It‘s a cuscus.

Helen: Here’s the stick.

Lillian (Hitting the cuscus): Aah! A good meal for tonight!

Helen: Yes, but you know those two told us to get vegetables.

Lillian: Rubbish! My stomach is already green with vegetables. I'm going to look for another kapul.

Helen: Try to cut this wild banana.

Lillian: You old woman. Cut it yourself.

Helen: What will we tell the girls and father?

Lillian: Sshhh! Watch out there. I'll cut this tree. (Cutting) Hurray! Another one.

Helen: Lily, you are so smart!

Lillian: Thanks. When we find another one, we'll call Dorah and Julie.

Helen: I can smell one. Let's look here. This time it will be mine.

Lillian: We're doing well. We'll find that one.

Helen: Yo— ho! It’s there. It’s there.

Lillian: I'll wait with the stick.

Helen: Dorah, Julie! A cuscus. A cuscus.

The two girls came running through the bushes.

Julie: Where is it?

Lillian: Up there. On that tree. Dorah, you cut the tree. Julie you hit it with the stick.

Julie: Gee! you've caught two. Now we’ve got a third one.

Lillian (laughing): It will be a change from the greens.

They go back home.

Julie: Papa, help us clean and cut the cuscus.

Papa: Cuscus?

Lillian (coming in): Yes, cuscus - I got them.

Everybody helps prepare the meal.

Mama (coming in): That was a long meeting! Hello girls.

Lillian (hugging her): Hi, Mum! Guess what I did in the bush today.

Mama: Mmmm collecting greens?

Lillian: No, not greens this time. Just go and see what Papa is doing at the back.

Mama: Wow! Who got those?

Lillian: Helen and I found them. We got two and the four of us got the other one.

Papa: Come on. Dinner is ready. Let’s eat.

Julie: Papa, Helen and Lillian wouldn't listen to us. They went off into the bush. They were very lazy.

Dorah: They didn't help us.

Lillian: We didn’t...! We weren’t...!

Papa: OK! OK! I know what you girls are like. But we won’t scold you today. After all, you did at least catch what we are eating!

texts:
Method:

1) Scrape the 20 coconuts. Add the water and squeeze them into a pot.

2) Leave overnight to allow the oil and cream to rise to the top.

3) Use the big spoon to separate the cream and oil from the top
of the coconut liquid. Scoop carefully so that you get only the
cream and oil.
4) Wash and scrape the bark of the noni root and keep the
scrapings. These will add colour and healing properties to the
oil.
5) Boil the cream and oil in a separate pot and add the bark of
the noni root.
6. When the oil is clear and yellow, it is ready.
7. Cool the oil and pour it into containers for use.

Jezreel's brother massaged his back with the noni oil. He did this every day for a week. Soon the ache went away.
"Ah! I feel much better now!" laughed Jezreel.
Noni oil has many uses. It can be used as a massage oil and a body and hair lotion. It doesn't cost anything to make, so it is better than buying an expensive lotion from the store and it has a lot of medical benefits.
We can also earn an income if we produce a surplus. If you are making noni oil like this, remember to take only a small part of the roots. You don't want to kill the tree.
Noni trees are a valuable resource in our environment, and we want to make sure they will be available for the next generation.

texts:
Then Rabbit went up the hill and down the other side.   There he saw Mr. Lion. “Good Morning,” he said, “What are you doing here?”

“This is where I live,” said the lion.

Then Rabbit told Lion. “I can pull you away from here.  I will pull you to the top of that hill.”

“You  can’t do that,” said Lion. “You are too small.”

“I will see you on Saturday,” he told the lion.

“Saturday, I will come and laugh,” said Lion. “But you can tie your rope around me then, if you like.”

Saturday came.  Rabbit tied one end of his rope on Hippo.  We don’t know just how he did that. (He didn’t tell us!) Then he went over the hill with the other end of the rope.

Rabbit visited Mr. Lion and tied the other end of his rope around him.

Rabbit went up the hill.  He came to the top.  He had his rope in his hands but he didn’t pull on it yet. There was a big tree with shade.  He rested under it.

The lion did not know the hippopotamus was there. The hippopotamus did not know the lion was there.   Each one thought, “I will laugh at this rabbit. I will pull him down.”Then Rabbit came out from under his tree and pulled the rope just a bit in the middle. Then the big animals started to move. They pulled and pulled. 

But they did not see any rabbit. They decided to pull themselves up on the rope. They had to see that rabbit.

They kept pulling until they came to the top. And there was the rabbit. He was dancing!

“Think and be strong,” he said.          (This legend comes from the Loma people in
                  up-country Liberia, West Africa.)

texts:
One day, a friend who worked at the mine was visiting Peter. He showed him some of the explosive powder they used in the mine.
“I put it in an empty Coca Cola bottle and it blows up like dynamite," he told Peter. "When I throw it in the sea, I get lots of fish."
Peter knew it was wrong to dynamite the reef. He knew that it was dangerous. He also knew that it killed all the fish in the area, even the baby ones. But Peter was lazy. “Give me some of that, and I’ll try it out next time I go fishing," he told his friend.
Peter was very proud of his new weapon, but the village people were terrified. “You'll blow yourself to pieces!" they told him. “And if you kill all the fish, there won't be any left for us to catch."
But Peter wouIdn‘t listen. “I'm not scared like you," he boasted.

The very next day, as soon as the tide was low enough, he went out onto the reef. Some men followed at a distance, curious to see how the dynamite would work. Peter lit the fuse and drew his arm back ready to throw. Behind him, Snoopy whined and wagged her tail.
The fuse hissed and sparked. Looking round proudly at the villagers, Peter threw the bottle. Splash! it went. And "Woof! Woof!"
Splash! In went Snoopy.
Everyone held their breath. "Snoopy is going to be blown to pieces! the men cried.
"Snoopy! No! Come back!" yelled Peter. But Snoopy was too excited. She snatched the bottle in her teeth and turned and swam back to Peter.

Peter raced over the dry reef, back to the shore. The bottle glinted in Snoopy’s mouth as she bounded proudly after him. Peter knew he was in real danger. They had played this game so many times. He knew the dynamite was coming for him. Snoopy would not rest|until she had laid the bottle at his feet. “Go back, Snoopy!" he cried as he ran for the village.
The men scattered. Some climbed the nearby coconut trees, some bolted for the village to warn the women and children.
“Run for your lives!" they cried. “Snoopy is coming with dynamite!"

There was a wild frenzy in the village as people ran for the bush. “Don't follow us!" they yelled at Peter. “Go back to the beach!It’s your dog and your dynamite! Don’t blow us all up!"
Peter turned and ran for the beach. Maybe he could hide from Snoopy along the shore. But Snoopy bounded behind him, the deadly bottle still in her mouth. Peter was gasping for breath. He could run no further. He collapsed on the ground. This was it. He said his final prayer.
When he had finished, he opened his eyes. Snoopy was sitting patiently, waiting for him to take the bottle and pat her like he usually did. Then Peter saw. The fuse wasn't sparking. It had gone out.
Relief flashed through him. He grabbed the bottle, pulled out the fuse, and rinsed the powder out into the sea. “It's all right now!" he called to the people. They ran up to see for themselves. Peter turned to Snoopy. "How could you make such a big fool out of me?" Then he started to laugh. The village people laughed, too. "Snoopy taught you a good lesson!" they teased him. “You got what you deserved!" They laughed as they went back to the village, “There is no dog in the whole village that is as smart as Snoopy!" they sang.

texts:
Did you know that crocodiles are shy animals?  Did you know that they close their mouths a lot faster than they open them?
And did you know that you can catch and hold small crocodiles when they are relaxed?
Mr Seeto knows these things, because he farms crocodiles on a small island near Madang. He catches young crocodiles and rears them for their skins.
Most of his young crocodiles come  from Ramu, Sepik, and New Ireland however, some also come from other places in Papua New Guinea, where salt water crocodiles live.

Mr. Seeto keeps them in pens according to their sizes. During the day, they lie around on the concrete floors of their pens, shaded by trees. But if they hear a noise, they dive into the water and hide under the boards he has put there for them. After a while, they will poke their heads out to see if it is safe. That’s how shy these little crocodiles are.
One of the biggest problems for a crocodile farmer is getting enough food for them. Mr. Seeto keeps crocodiles until they are three years old and at that age they eat two kilograms of meat a day. Mr. Seeto has an arrangement with a nearby poultry abattoir to take all their waste meat.

He feeds the crocodiles once a day, in the evening, so that the flies don't sit on the meat all day.
When Mr. Seeto wants to pick up one of the crocodiles, he puts a big rubber band around its jaws to keep them shut. He can do this because even though a crocodile can snap its mouth shut quickly, it can only open it slowly. He still has to watch out for the thrusting tail.
For the three-year-olds that are ready to kill, he needs help. They are getting too big to hold easily. He puts a bag over their eyes to keep them quiet. When the crocodile is relaxed again, it is killed with a quick blow on the head with the back of a small axe.
He skins the crocodile carefully so that the skin is not damaged. A first-grade skin will sell for export at K400, to be made into expensive leather shoes, belts, briefcases, and handbags. Crocodile meat also sells - mainly to top restaurants and big hotels.
Mr. Seeto is not rich. It costs a lot of money to build crocodile pens, to feed the crocodiles, and to pay the people who help him.
And he is learning all the time. But he has started a new kind of farming for Papua New Guinea that others can copy, and that will earn more money and provide more jobs for the people of the country.

texts:
The part of the earth north of the equator is called the Northern Hemisphere. The part south of the equator is called the Southern Hemisphere. 

Seasons can change as Earth tilts more toward the sun or away from the sun. When it tilts toward the sun, it receives the sun's most direct rays. This causes warmer weather. When it tilts away, the weather is cooler. When the North Pole tilts toward the sun it is summer in the Northern Hemisphere. When the South Pole tilts toward the sun it is winter in the Northern Hemisphere.The temperature is usually cooler at higher altitudes and warmer close to sea level. At higher altitudes the air is thinner and does not hold as much of the sun's heat.

If there are lakes, rivers or oceans in the area, there is not as much change in temperature throughout the year. There is not as much change in temperature between daytime and nighttime. That is because water hold its temperature longer than land does. Over large areas of land there is more difference in temperature.

The movement of winds can change weather also. For example, the Himalayan mountains in Pakistan, Nepal and other countries act like a high wall. They block winds from passing into central Asia. As the winds rise the air grows cooler, and the result can be rain or snow. In cold weather, strong winds make the air feel colder.

Some countries do not have spring, summer, autumn and winter. They have rain time and dry time, or “rainy season” and “dry season.” These seasons are different in different countries. In parts of North Africa the rains come from November to March. Then from July to September it is quite dry. Liberia has a dry season from November to March and it is very hot, with no rain to cool off the air. But in the Democratic Republic of the Congo the dry time is from May to September. That is when clouds cover over the sun almost every day, so it is much cooler than the rain time.

Most of Africa has a “tropical climate.” That means it is hot, with much moisture in the air. But in the north of Africa it is different. Morocco, Egypt, Tunisia and Algeria have a very dry desert climate. They have no rainy season. Inland, many places stay dry all year because they are close to the Sahara Desert, but some areas along the coast have rain.

South and East Asia have very heavy rains every year. These rains are called monsoons. Parts of India average over 400 inches of rain a year. Much of that is from the monsoons. Southern China, Korea, and parts of Japan also have monsoons. Southern Asia has a mild to hot climate. But Siberia in the far northeast is very cold. The largest country of central Asia is Kazakhstan. It has all four seasons: spring, summer, autumn and winter.

Most of South America has the four seasons. But some areas have rain time and dry time. Bolivia, Ecuador, and Peru are dry and cold from November through May. Brazil and Colombia have a more temperate climate year round. There is plenty of rain to keep the rain forests of Peru and Brazil growing. The coldest parts of South America are in southern Argentina and Chile. They reach almost as far south as Antarctica.North America has the four seasons: spring, summer, autumn and winter. Autumn is also called “fall” because that is the time of year when leaves fall off the trees. The countries and islands of Central America are quite warm. As we move north the climate generally gets cooler, until we reach the very cold areas of northern Canada and Alaska.

The seventh continent, Antarctica, is the coldest of all. Only a little more than 1% of the land is free of ice. Temperatures fall to -100 degrees Fahrenheit or -70 degrees Centigrade. Scientists and others come there for short periods of time to study or to visit but no one lives there all the time. Very few plants can grow. The only animals in Antarctica are whales, seals, penguins and birds that visit from other places.

We find that certain animals and plants can live in some places but not in others. That brings us to another question. How do seasons affect our lives? Most important is the question of growing food. Where there is good soil, sunlight and warm enough weather, we can plant fruits and vegetables and raise animals. There must also be enough water, either from rain or from irrigation. If we do not have these things, we cannot grow food.
predicted_texts: The Earth orbits the Sun. When the northern hemisphere is tilted towards the sun, it experiences summer. Simultaneously, the southern hemisphere experiences winter. The opposite occurs when the southern hemisphere tilts towards the sun.
During winter, people often wear warmer clothing and use umbrellas to shield themselves from rain or snow. The weather can be harsh, and staying dry and warm is essential for health and comfort.
Kazakhstan, a large country in Central Asia, experiences cold winters with significant snowfall. Turkmenistan, located further south, has milder winters but can still get quite chilly.

In South America, Chile and Argentina experience winter during the northern hemisphere's summer. The seasons are reversed due to their location south of the equator. This means that while some are swimming, others are skiing.
As spring returns, the weather warms, and people start planting seeds in anticipation of a bountiful harvest. The cycle of seasons influences agriculture and daily life across the globe.

texts:
Teacher: Thank you, Tevita. Where are they?

Teacher: Thank you, Annie.

- They look out the window. -

Annie: Look! There’s smoke!

Tevita: It’s coming from the kunai!

David: Mmmm! It’s almost cooked.

Harold: I'm going to eat lots!

Teacher (to children): Wait here!

- She marches of to the kunai patch. -

“Where did you boys get this corn?”

Harold: From the Eagles‘ garden.

Teacher: From the Eagles‘ garden?

Myra: Hey! That is our corn!

Teacher: Well, thank you boys for making a fire for the Eagles. Thank you for harvesting their corn and cooking it for them. Now go and wait in the line.

- The children all laugh. -

Children: Ha! Ha! No corn for you!

Teacher (calling): Eagles, Eagles, come and eat your corn, 

Myra: Come on girls, let‘s go.

- They sit around the fire. -

Myra: Mmmm! It’s delicious.

Annie: Corn! My favourite.

Tevita: It’s the best corn I‘ve ever tasted.

Later, outside, Mrs. Okoro confronted a group of students huddled around a small fire. Her voice was firm as she questioned them about the smoke she had seen earlier.
The students, initially sheepish, began to explain how they were roasting corn and the fire had gotten a bit out of control. Mrs. Okoro listened intently, the weight of their actions sinking in.

texts:
Scene: The bush.MAGANI: (hopping in) I want to go to Koiari, but it’s a hot day I don’t want to walk so far. What can I do?
(He hops around the stage) Hmm 'I,ve got an idea. I'll just lie down and hold my leg...
MOMOT: (scuttling in) Hello, Magani. What’s the matter with you?
MAGANI: Oh, Momot. Thank goodness you came along. I’ve broken my leg, and I’ve got to get to Koiari. Will you carry me?
MOMOT: Sorry. I’d like to help, but I am too small.
(Momot runs off into the bush.)

Scene: The bush.MAGANI: Ah! Here comes Torosel.  (MAGANI holds his leg) Ow! Oh oh ow!
TOROSEL: (crawling in) Hello Magani. What’s wrong? Are  you hurt?
MAGANI: Oh, yes, Torosel my friend. I’ve broken my leg. You are just the one who can help me. I’ve got to get to Koiari. Will you carry me?
TOROSEL: I’d love to but I would take a long time. I am too slow.
MAGANI: Oh how lazy my friends are! Nobody wants to help me. What shall I do? Ah! Here comes Kapul! Ow! Ow!
KAPUL (climbing down): Hello, Magani. What’s the matter?
MAGANI: Oh, Kapul. Thank goodness you’ve come. I’ve broken my leg. Maybe you can help me. I’ve got to get to Koiari. Will you carry me?
KAPUL: I’d like to help. But I only climb trees. I can’t go that far on the ground. Sorry.
(She climbs back up her tree.)

MAGANI: What am I going to do? I don’t want to have to walk all the way to Koiari myself. Ah! Here comes Rusa! Ow! Ow! My leg! My leg!
RUSA: (running in) Hello, Magani. What’s the matter?
MAGANI: It’s my leg. It’s broken and I’ve got to get to Koiari. Will you carry me?
RUSA: Oh dear. Poor Magani.
(To audience) Hmm. I wonder if he's tricking me. I think I can find out (To MAGANI). All right, Magani. I’ll carry you. Get onto my back.
MAGANI: Thank you, Rusa (He pulls himself onto RUSA’s back).
RUSA: Off we go, around this tree.
MAGANI: Not so fast, Rusa. I’m slipping!
RUSA: And over this log.
MAGANI: Not so fast, Rusa. l’m slipping!
RUSA: And under this branch.
MAGANI: Not so fast, Rusa. I’m slipping!
RUSA: And over this stream.

MAGANI: Not so fast, Rusa. I’m slipping! Oh no, I’m slipping!
(Magani lands splash in the water. He stands up.)
RUSA: Why Magani, you are standing up. I don’t think your leg was broken after all.
(All the animals come in and laugh at Magani.)
MAGANI: My trick didn’t work. Now I shall have to walk all the way to Koiari.
(Magani hops slowly away, while the others laugh at him.)
predicted_texts: In the vast expanse of the Australian outback, lived a kangaroo named Kevin. Unlike his peers who were always in a rush, Kevin enjoyed the simple pleasures of life. He often sat atop his favorite rock, contemplating the world around him.

One day, as Kevin was enjoying his quiet time, he noticed a commotion below. A turtle, a rat, and an opossum were arguing. Their bickering echoed through the usually silent landscape, disturbing Kevin's peace.

Curiosity piqued, Kevin hopped down to investigate. As he approached, he saw a majestic deer standing nearby, seemingly unbothered by the quarrel. Kevin, always eager to help, offered the deer a ride, hoping to get a better view of the situation.

From atop the deer, Kevin surveyed the scene. He realized the animals were arguing over a small patch of berries. With a sigh, Kevin hopped down and mediated the dispute, reminding them of the importance of sharing and cooperation. Soon, the animals were friends again, enjoying the berries together, and Kevin returned to his rock, content with his role as a peacemaker.

In a small village, a craftsman meticulously assembled a table and chair. The smooth surfaces and sturdy construction were a testament to his skill. He knew that his work would soon grace a home, providing comfort and functionality to its inhabitants.

The axe fell silent as the great tree crashed to the earth. The birds scattered, their songs replaced by the heavy thud and the rustle of falling leaves. The man stood there, contemplating his actions, knowing that he had forever altered the landscape.

texts: After we were done preparing, we started our journey at 7:00am. I looked smart and beautiful.

After walking for some metres we got to the bus station but there were no vehicles.
                                It was now 9:00am and no vehicle had shown up. People become so impatient but after a long wait the bus eventually arrived.

After four hours of waiting,a bus arrived
                                and we boarded but before the bus could depart a woman came running and requested one of the passengers to alight so that she would get a seat since
                                she was was going for work yet she was very late.
                                No one was willing to stand so that she could get a seat and so I requested my mother if we could vacate the seat for her.
                                My mother agreed and we alighted the bus to wait for another bus. After 10 minutes, another bus arrived
                                and we boarded.

The bus was moving very fast and after an hour we arrived to the school that I was going to be admitted.
                                As we got into the school compound, we found a very big queue of parents and their children waiting to be served.

Immediately we got to the administration block, we saw that lady who we had vacated the seat for. She was surprised to see us too. She called us and I was
                                admitted without making the queue. We later realized that she was the headteacher of that school.
                                It was because of our humbleness that we were favored.

predicted_texts: Jonah was a prophet in Israel. One day, God told him to go to the great city of Nineveh and preach against its wickedness.
But Jonah disobeyed God. He went down to Joppa and found a ship bound for Tarshish, far away from Nineveh. He paid his fare and went aboard, hoping to escape God's command.
The Lord sent a great wind upon the sea, and there was a mighty tempest. The sailors were afraid, and each cried out to his god. They cast the cargo into the sea to lighten the ship.
Then the sailors said to one another, "Come, let us cast lots, that we may know for whose cause this trouble has come upon us." So they cast lots, and the lot fell on Jonah.

The Lord appointed a great fish to swallow Jonah, and he was in the belly of the fish three days and three nights. From inside the fish, Jonah prayed to the Lord his God, repenting of his disobedience.

The tiny spark grew, slowly, tentatively. It pulsed with a faint, ethereal light, pushing back against the encroaching shadows. It was a beacon, a promise that even in the deepest darkness, hope could still ignite.

texts:
A large lion was sleeping in the shade of a Nimm tree when a little mouse ran across his tummy. This tickled the lion, so he grabbed the little mouse. The mouse squeaked with fear. “Oh, please do not eat me,” squeaked the mouse, “I’m so small I would not even make one good bite. Let me go, and someday I could be useful to you.”
“Now that is funny!” roared the lion, “How could a little thing like you ever help me, the king of all the animals?”
But the lion let the mouse go.

Weeks and weeks went by.

One day the little mouse heard the large lion roaring. The noisy lion seemed to be in great pain. The mouse ran to the lion. He had been caught by hunters. His soft paws were tied with thick rope.

The mouse began to gnaw the rope with his sharp little teeth. He worked a long, long time. At last the lion was free!

The mouse said, “There, you see! You would be in big trouble if it was not for me.”
 The grateful lion smiled. “So I see, my little friend. So I see.”
predicted_texts: Once upon a time, there lived a tiny mouse. He was a humble creature, always scurrying about, minding his own business. But little did he know, his life was about to take a very unexpected turn.

One day, the mouse heard a mighty roar. Trembling, he peeked out from his hiding spot and saw a magnificent lion trapped in a hunter's net. The lion's powerful struggles only tightened the ropes, and despair filled his eyes.

Without a second thought, the brave little mouse darted forward. Ignoring his fear, he began gnawing at the thick ropes with his sharp teeth. Slowly, steadily, he chewed through the cords, freeing the mighty lion.

texts: Amani and his family listened to the news and were very happy when they heard that some scientists had developed several vaccines against this horrible disease. People in other countries were starting to get them. Finally, they heard the good news that their own country had managed to buy some vaccine and had also been given some vaccine from a central fund. It was a happy day when the President announced that they would begin vaccinating everyone over 70 years and those who were working in hospitals or clinics. Amani expected everyone to be delighted, but he soon found out that wasn't true. The local Government had asked if the 2 largest churches in town could be used to give the vaccine. This meant his church and the Catholic church down the road.  Both agreed willingly, but soon found this wasn't as simple as they thought!

First, one of Amani's deacons came around to the house, looking very cross. "Why are you letting our church be used to give the vaccine?" he asked crossly. "I’ve heard that this is a plot of the West to put computer chips in us so that they will control us." Amani patiently explained that this was a vaccine just like the measles or polio vaccine and no one could get a chip through the needle. The deacon left not sure what to believe.The next day the team arrived from the capital and set up ready to vaccinate the first people. Amani's father had received an invitation to get a vaccine, but he came round to see his son looking very worried."I've read about this vaccine," he said. They developed it in just a year. They say normally it takes many years to develop vaccines. How do I know it is safe? Maybe it will make me very ill!" Amani explained that it had been tested on thousands of people and proved to be very safe. He said, "It was done quickly because they had many scientists working on it, and large sums of money went into the research. Please go and get the vaccine, Dad! I don't want you to get sick and die!" Finally, his dad went and had the vaccine.

Peter, the priest at the other large church, and Amani would meet every two weeks or so to discuss any problems they needed to deal with together. This time they sat outside a little apart, both wearing masks as they discussed how the vaccine team was getting on. Amani told Peter about his problems with some people who didn't want the vaccine."Well, I've been told some amazing stories," said Peter. “One of my members told me no one should get the vaccine because it would give you the mark of Satan! I asked him why he thought that, and he showed me some weird post on the internet that said this.I had to try to convince him that not everything you find on the internet is true! I showed him some other impossible things on the internet, like people saying the earth is flat, and now he understands that you cannot believe everything you read online!”

As time went on, people started to have trust in the vaccine. The team gave the first vaccine to most of the older people and hospital workers in the town. Everyone was told as well that they would need a second injection some weeks later before they would have all the resistance possible to the disease. After that, they started vaccinating younger people.Some of the people, who had received the first vaccine, complained a bit that they had sore arms and didn't feel well for a couple of days. However, most people decided that a sore arm was better than dying! So Amani and Peter’s efforts brought blessing to their whole community.

With a gentle smile and a reassuring word, she administered the vaccine, watching as relief washed over the faces of those she helped protect.

This is what you do: 
1. Build the small fire. Wash your hands.

2. Measure the flour, sugar and oil into the bowl.

3. Mash the ripe bananas, add them to the bowl, and mix.

4. Add 1/3 cup water and stir the mixture until it is all wet and sticks together. You may add a little water if the dough is too firm.

5. Place the frying pan on the small fire. Drop a few drops of oil into the frying pan. Spread the oil around. Wait for the frying pan to get hot.

6. Put spoonfuls of dough into the frying pan. With the spoon spread the dough to flatten it. Put more spoonfuls of dough in the frying pan flattening each scone.
Fill the frying pan with scones leaving space between each one.

7. Cover the frying pan with the lid.
Wait 3-5 minutes.  Turn the scones over. Wait 3-5 minutes. Sniff the air to smell how the scones are cooking. Burned scones are OK. But they are better if they are not burned.

8. Repeat the steps 5-7 until all the dough is cooked.

9. Share the banana scones with your family or friends.

You might know a person who has many friends. Other people admire that person. They want to be like him or her. You want to have lots of friends, too. You want it so much that you start to have bad feelings toward that person. You get angry. You are coveting.You might covet the money a rich person has. Or the success your neighbor has in his business. You tried to go into business and you failed. You might covet the fame of a football star, or a governor or a president. You want to be famous, too.

You may covet someone’s good looks. You may covet someone’s ability to sing, to draw or to show some other talent that you don’t have. You might covet another person’s strong or pleasant voice. You may covet a person’s ability to speak in front of other people.

It’s all right to want some of these things. You can work hard to have them for yourself. It’s all right to admire something that belongs to someone else. lt is all right to admire what he has done. But it is not all right to have bad feelings toward that person. It is not good to push others out of your way in order to get what they have. That would be coveting.

When you covet, you have a strong desire. You long for something. You set your heart on it. You want it too much. You want it more than you want to be with God.

Have you seen signs about things you can buy? “This soap will get you very clean.” Or “Real men smoke Lightup cigarettes.” You may read sentences like that in a magazine. You may hear them on the radio or on television. This is called advertising.

Instead of stealing something, it is better to picture the person who owns it enjoying it. You may not know how he got it or how much it means to him. Then picture something else you could enjoy just as much, something you do not need to steal. Using dishonest weights is stealing, too. Charging too much money is stealing.

“Do not bear false witness.” That means do not lie. You may lie to keep yourself safe, to not be punished. Or you may want to keep someone else safe who is guilty. You don’t want others to know that you did something wrong, or that the person you are protecting did something wrong. Or it could be just the opposite: a person did not do anything wrong but you say that he did.  

If you tell the truth but only part of the truth, that is as bad as lying. This makes it look like things happened differently. This can happen in a courtroom. It can also happen when you are talking with your friends or family.

Jesus said, “Take heed and beware of covetousness, for one’s life does not consist in the abundance of the things he possesses.” (Luke 12:15, King James Version.) To say this another way, “Watch out and guard yourselves from every kind of greed, because your true life is not made up of the things you own.” (Luke 12:15, Good News translation)

Paul teaches us to be satisfied with whatever God gives us, whether it is a little or a lot. He wrote, “I know what it is to be in need and what it is to have more than enough. I have learned this secret so that anywhere, at any time, I am content, whether full or hungry, whether I have too much or too little.” (Philippians 4:12, Good News translation)

Ask the Holy Spirit to show you when you are wanting something else more than you want God. God is pleased when we do not covet. He is pleased when we are grateful for His gifts and blessings, whatever they are.
predicted_texts: Mark glanced at his watch, a gift from his parents, a reminder of their love and support. He appreciated it, but lately, he'd been wanting something more, something newer.

He saw his friends gathered, laughing and talking about their latest purchases. They flaunted their new clothes and gadgets, and Mark felt a pang of envy. He wanted to be part of their world, their world of possessions.

An advertisement caught his eye, a perfume ad promising luxury and allure. The image of the model and the promise of transformation stirred something within him. He wanted that feeling, that sense of having something desirable.

He walked into a store, gazing at the shelves filled with expensive items. He picked up a box, feeling its weight, imagining how it would feel to own it. The desire was overwhelming, a hunger he couldn't ignore.

But then, he remembered the words of wisdom he'd once heard, 'Thou shalt not covet.' He paused, the weight of the box feeling heavier now, not with desire, but with guilt. He realized that true happiness wasn't found in possessions, but in contentment and gratitude.

texts:
As an adolescent I used to help my father chop wood, dig drains, and build fences and pigs’ huts. Sometimes I would go hunting with my friends. The jungle was full of beautiful birds and many wild animals. We never went far before we caught a bird or a cuscus. Later I was my own boss. I built my own house, and made my own gardens. I ate food grown with my own hands.
I knew the landmarks and the boundaries well. I knew the tricks and the trade of hunting. I would catch birds or cuscus anytime I needed meat. I used to go on walkabouts through the land. I would carry my axe, my spear and my bows and arrows.
My axe would go thud, thud, thud.
My spear would go swoosh, swoosh, swoosh.
And my bows and arrows would go wisssh wisssh, wisssh.

I would return from my walkabouts with wood on my shoulder and birds and cuscus in my hands.
I would enter the small, low kunai house, where the warmth of a glowing fire and the smell of mumu food always made me feel welcome.
Now I am a man, I have a small son who crawls  to the small stream near the house.
This is my village. This is where my father was. This is where I am. This is where my son will be. This is where we all entered the world. This is where we all will lie when we die. This is our home.

Some of the animals and birds were so tame, that it was not hard for Noah to gather them together. Among these were the doves and pigeons, who all belong to the same family of birds. They love to live with people and to make their home with them. They can learn to carry messages for them as the carrier pigeons do. When they fly out, they also fly back home.

When God was ready for Noah and his family to make their home in the new boat, the Ark, the doves and pigeons Noah chose were happy to go along with them. God even made some of every kind of wild animal willing to make the Ark their home because God can get the attention and respect of all these creatures.

Now among these birds there was a dove. This dove liked to sit on Noah’s shoulder or on his arm. He liked to look Noah in the eye. Noah liked all the birds and animals, but he especially noticed this dove.

After the big Flood that covered all the earth and after the earth began to dry, the Ark was sitting on a mountain. Everybody in it was excited, wondering when they would be able to get out of the Ark and stretch their legs or wings. Noah waited until God told him when to open a window in the Ark. Then Noah let a raven, or crow, go out first.

This big bird would be strong and able to fly far. It went off, flapping its wings. But the raven never came back. It had decided to go wherever it wanted to go, and it didn’t care about all the people and other creatures in the Ark, waiting to find out what it was like outside.

God led him to do just the right thing, and that was to clip off a twig of olive leaf and hold it in his beak. Suddenly he felt so joyful. This was it. This was how he could tell Noah without being able to speak to him. He rose from the branch where he had been sitting and headed home to the Ark.

As the bird got close, one of Noah’s sons saw the dove and called out, “The bird has something in its beak.” The window was crowded with those who wanted to see, too. Then Noah reached out his hand, and the dove landed. Noah reached for the olive leaf, and the dove let him take it.“Look at this!” Noah exclaimed. “It is almost time for us to leave the Ark. God has sent us this message by the dove. Thanks be to God! And thank you, faithful dove.”

texts:
Mother Teresa  1910 – 1997     

Mother Teresa spent her life helping the poor, the needy, and the helpless.

She was born in Macedonia in 1910. Her birth name was Agnes but she changed her name to Teresa when she became a nun. She grew up attending the Roman Catholic Church and decided to devote her life to God. She wanted to be a missionary in India but first had to learn to speak English.

In 1929, aged 19, she began her missionary work as a teacher in a school in Indian. She learned the local Indian language. She taught for many years in India becoming the headmistress of a school in Calcutta.When she was 36 years old Mother Teresa felt the call from God to help the poor living in India. She received some basic medical training and then began to help the sick and needy. This wasn’t easy in 1948 in India.
While trying to feed the poor she herself was constantly hungry and even had to beg for food. She began an open-air school and a home for the dying destitute.

In 1950 Mother Teresa formed a group called the ‘Missionaries of Charity’. Their aim was to care for: “the hungry, the naked, the homeless, the crippled, the blind, the lepers, all those people who feel unwanted, unloved, uncared for.” She established a leper colony, an orphanage, a nursing home, and mobile health clinics.

Eventually the ‘Missionaries of Charity’ worked in 123 countries around the world. In 1979 Mother Teresa was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her work “in bringing help to suffering humanity.”  She worked almost up until her death in September 1997.
predicted_texts: In the heart of Calcutta, stood a woman of unwavering resolve. Her name was synonymous with compassion, a beacon of hope amidst despair. Clad in a simple habit, she dedicated her life to the poorest of the poor, a testament to selfless service.

With gentle guidance, she nurtured the minds of young children, imparting knowledge and instilling values. Her classroom was a haven, where education was a tool to uplift and empower, breaking the chains of poverty and ignorance.

Her embrace radiated warmth, a sanctuary for orphaned and abandoned children. She cradled them with tenderness, showering them with love and care, reminding them that they were not forgotten, that they were cherished.

texts:
People also ask
How can we prevent dengue?
Apply mosquito repellent, ideally one containing DEET.
Wear long-sleeves and long pants to cover your arms and legs.
Use mosquito nets while sleeping.
Read on to find out some steps you can take to protect your home from the Aedes mosquito.​

Here are some key points about dengue fever:-
Dengue is transmitted by the mosquitoes Aedes aegypti  and Aedes albopictus , which are found throughout the world.
Around 2.5 billion people, or 40 percent of the world's population, live in areas where there is a risk of dengue transmission.
Dengue is endemic in at least 100 countries in Asia, the Pacific, the Americas, Africa, and the Caribbean.
Symptoms usually begin 4 to 7 days after the mosquito bite and typically last 3 to 10 days.
Effective treatment is possible if a clinical diagnosis is made early.
Above Picture is showing the Symptoms of Dengue Fever

Dengue is a virus, so there is no specific treatment or cure. However, intervention can help, depending on how severe the disease is.
For milder forms, treatment includes:
Preventing dehydration: A high fever and vomiting can dehydrate the body. The person should drink clean water, ideally bottled rather than tap water. Rehydration salts can also help replace fluids and minerals.
Painkillers, such as Tylenol or paracetamol: These can help lower fever and ease pain.
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin or ibuprofen, are not advised, as they can increase the risk of internal bleeding.
predicted_texts: The Aedes aegypti mosquito, a small but dangerous creature, is known for its distinctive black and white markings.
This mosquito acts as a vector, transmitting diseases like dengue fever between humans.

Dengue fever manifests with a range of symptoms. The initial febrile phase brings sudden fever, headache, and muscle pain. In severe cases, it can progress to a critical phase with complications like bleeding and organ damage.
The symptoms of dengue can be scary. They include high fever, headache, muscle pain, pain behind the eyes, skin rashes, vomiting, and bleeding from the mouth and nose.

WHEN A LAW HAS LOVE


A small village was very poor. There was not enough food. The chief called the people together. He said, “We must share our food. I now make this new law. Each person take only his share. Do not take more. You may be punished.”The next day the people came to the chief. They said, “One person did not obey the law. What shall we do?” The chief answered, “We must punish that person. I will give him a beating. That is the law.”

The chief asked, “Who is this person?” The people answered, “The person is your mother. Will you beat your own mother?”

The chief said, “No! I love my mother. But I made the law. I cannot change it. I will take the punishment. Beat me — instead of my mother.”

texts:
You can only see her at night. When storm clouds gather and the sea is calm and still. When the birds perch in the trees and the fish dart beneath the sea.

You can only see her at night. When the moon is full and way up in the sky. When a cool breeze blows and rustles the leaves.

She starts to sing, her voice, soft, sweet, and sad.

The sounds of drums and flutes and pipes whisper in the air.
She walks along the shore, tall and slim like a coconut tree. Then she starts to dance like the rising waves.

Her hips sway to the beat, her hands holding flowers of pink, and blue, and white. Her black hair hangs to her waist. Her eyes so wide, black and curious, her skin so brown and smooth.

At times she sits and watches the sea, watches the waves move to and fro. A crab crawls by, pokes the sand, and burrows. But only when she is alone, when all is calm and still.
If she sees you, she’ll flee, and hide, and dive, and stop her swaying hips. The music will fade off into the night.
You’ll stand and rub your eyes and shake your head. You’ll walk to the place where she was standing. But she’ll be gone, gone, gone. Then you’ll see a lonely canoe, with a lonely island man. A lonely island man and a girl from the sea. Together they’ll paddle away. Then you’ll see them no more; only the waves, and the fish in the sea. You'll see them no more. But you’ll hear her voice, the drums, the pipe, and the flute, way out at sea.

texts:
The chief ’s daughter was a very beautiful girl. The chief loved her very much. But one day, as she was doing her sweeping around the house the Thunder Man came and stole her away.
“Boom! Boom! Bang! Boom! Boom! Bang!” the thunder roared and the beautiful girl disappeared just like that.
The chief and his wife were very sad.
They cried all night. Next day they called everyone to their place. The chief promised that whoever could bring back his daughter, could marry her.

The bush fowl was the first one to try, but he got only to the top of the house and the wind blew him down. The fat owl tried next, but he got only as high as the top of the trees, and fell. Then the big great eagle tried, and he got very close to the clouds.
“Here, let me try,” the rainbow bird said quietly from behind. Everyone laughed.
“How can you succeed where the great eagle has failed?” they asked.
But the rainbow bird walked straight to the front of the crowd. He opened his wings and began to fly up. He flew up and up, higher and higher. The people looked and looked. The rainbow bird became smaller and smaller. Then he was lost among the grey clouds.
“Hooray!” everyone shouted.

“Be quiet I have not yet seen my daughter,” the chief shouted. “Until I see my daughter with my own eyes, I will not be happy. Go home now, and we’ll try again tomorrow.”
One by one, the creatures began to go home.
Early the next morning, the chief was woken by a very sweet voice.
“Pero, Pero! Pero, Pero!”
He could not believe what he heard. But slowly he sat up, opened the door, and crept silently out. There, on top of his roof was the rainbow bird calling, “Pero, Pero!” — and right near the steps stood his smiling daughter. She was still beautiful.
As he had promised, the chief invited everyone to a big feast to celebrate the marriage of his daughter to the rainbow bird.

When it thunders today, it means that the Thunder Man is coming to look for the girl and to take his revenge on the rainbow bird. And be careful not to get in his way!
When you feel the wind on your face, you will know that the Thunder Man has just passed by.
When Thunder Man cannot find the beautiful girl, he’ll cry and cry, wetting you and filling all the rivers.
When the Thunder Man turns away, then you will see the rainbow bird flying across the sky with his beautiful wife.

texts:
That morning, as Dhani fed Binni with fresh grass and
                        changed the water in her bowl, he said, “Something’s
                        up, Binni! They all sit and talk in Gandhiji’s room. They
                        are planning something. I know it!”

                        Binni chewed and nodded as if she understood.
                        Dhani felt hungry. He headed towards the kitchen, with Binni skipping along beside him. His mother was
                        fanning the chulha, filling up the room with smoke.

                        “Amma, is Gandhiji going somewhere?” he asked. His
                        mother coughed in the smoke and said, “They are going on a march.”

                        “March? Where are they going?” Dhani queried.
                        “Somewhere near the sea. Now stop asking questions
                        and go away Dhani!” his mother said impatiently. “Let
                        me finish the cooking first.”

                        Dhani wandered off to the vegetable garden where old
                        Binda was digging up potatoes.

“Binda chacha,” Dhani sat beside him, “are you going on the march too?”

                        Binda shook his head. Before he could say anything,
                        Dhani eagerly asked, “Who is marching? Where are they going? What is happening?”

                        Binda stopped digging and said, “I’ll answer all your
                        questions, but first tie up that troublesome goat. She’s
                        chewing up my spinach.”

                        Dhani dragged Binni away and tied her to the lemon
                        tree nearby. Then Binda told him about the march.
                        Gandhiji and some of the men from the ashram were
                        going to walk through Gujarat to reach the sea at a place called Dandi. They would walk through villages and towns for a whole month. Once they reached Dandi, they would make salt.

His father stopped spinning and explained patiently, “Only the people who have been chosen by Mahatmaji will go.”

                        “Fine! I’ll talk to him then! I’m sure he’ll say yes,” said
                        Dhani and marched off.

                        Gandhiji was a very busy man and it was not easy to
                        catch him alone. But Dhani knew exactly when he would have the time to listen – early every morning when he went for a walk around the ashram.

                        The next morning, as the sun came up, Dhani slipped
                        out of bed and went looking for Gandhiji. He found him
                        in the cowshed checking on all the cows. Then he
                        strolled into the vegetable garden to inspect the peas
                        and cabbage and have a chat with Binda.

All the while, Dhani and Binni followed him.
                        Finally, Gandhiji headed back to his hut. He sat down
                        beside his charkha in the verandah and called out to
                        Dhani, “Come here, child!” Dhani ran up, with Binni
                        skipping along.

                        “What’s your name beta?”

                        “Dhani, Gandhiji.”

                        “And this is your goat?”

                        “Yes, Gandhiji! This is my friend Binni, who gives the
                        milk you drink every morning.” Dhani smiled proudly
                        and said, “I take care of her.”

                        “Good!” Gandhiji leaned forward. “Now Dhani, tell me
                        why you and Binni have been following me everywhere this morning?”

“Hmm, you’re right, Gandhiji. Binni eats only when I
                        feed her.” Dhani lovingly stroked Binni’s head, “And only I know what she likes to eat.”

                        “Exactly! So will you stay in the ashram and take care of Binni for me?”

                        "Yes, Gandhiji, I will,” said Dhani. “And Binni and I will be waiting for you.”
