texts:
Growing a garden is hard work.  Once the seeds are planted, they must be watered, and the soil kept loose around the young plants.  Weeds must be pulled so they do not crowd out the good plants.      It had been dry since Sabu plant-
ed these seeds, and he was really hoping it would rain soon.

Listen!  What was that sound? Sabu stopped working and looked up.  He saw flashes of lightning.

     It was going to storm.  The rain should save his plants.

Suddenly, Sabu felt something hit his head.  It was bigger than a rain- drop.  He looked around and could not believe what he was seeing.
     Fish were falling from  the sky!  All colors.  And different sizes. Sabu began running back to his house.

The fish helped enrich the soil, and the rain brought the plants back to life again.
     Sabu's garden produced a very good crop that year.  And he has never forgotten  the day that fish fell out of the sky!

texts:
Varap is a special kind of Seaweed - a sea vegetable which is eaten by Buka people in North Bougainville.

It grows on stones and coral along the edge of the reef. The Buka people like its strong salty taste.

It gives off good flavour when eaten with kaukau, coconut, or other starchy foods.

On some islands, children sometmes take it in their school lunch. It is a healthy food that has vitamins and minerals, so it is very good for you.

It is especially good for pregnant women. Some people say that it can even help prevent stomach cancer.
The Buka people dive for it and bring it ashore.
They wash it in a bowl with sea water and remove any bad bits.

They don’t take the roots off.

They wrap the seaweed in gorgor leaves and stand parcels upright to drain.

If kept cool it will keep for up to a week.
This kind of seaweed also fetches a good price in the Buka market, so it is another way people can earn money.

texts:
He kept running, balancing the basket on his head and reached the river. He could not find any shelter.
                                Soon, the basket on his head started moving vigorously.
                                Ramu could not control it and he fell in the river. Moti also jumped to save Ramu. All the fishes went into the water. Ramu got hold of his umbrella and both of them climbed in. Billu stayed back on the shore.

The river took them along with it. The rains were heavy and they drifted a long way from the shore. Ramu was scared as he did not know what to do.
                                Soon, the rains stopped, but the umbrella were going down the river. The river had calmed down. Suddenly, they saw a shoal of fish in the water. They decided to follow. Ramu rowed with his hands and followed the fishes.

They saw the rainbow in the water; they also saw other fishes jumping in and out of the water. As they kept going, suddenly Ramu saw the shore, where Billu is waiting and started rowing faster. Soon, they reached the shore.
                                They thanked the fished and they went away. They said, "Thank You for letting us go." Ramu went back home, empty-handed.

He told his mother that the basket fell into the river and he lost all the fishes. Billu agreed, "Meow", and Moti too, "Woof." Ramu looked at them and smiled.
                                Ramu lost the day's earning, but made new friends, who helped him in the rain. The day turned out to be fun.
                                Next day, he went to the river again and, suddenly, Moti fell in the water. Will Ramu set out on a new adventure?

Here are some other people who suffered but found joy:  The man who kept thousands of poor children out of the weather in England (George Mueller).  A little boy we could think about, who cried to his dad.  He just “had to” own a pair of special shoes.  Then he realized that the shoes really “owned” him.  He gave up his desires and used his money to help a mission instead.

A lame man washed pots day after day for years in a religious house about 350 years ago. This man was Brother Lawrence. He lived in France. He had lost a leg in a war. He often lived in much pain. There was no medicine to take the pain away. He worked hard and had to carry heavy things. He labored in his mind to give all his thoughts to God. He was seen by many as being calm and wise.  A young American brought thousands of “street kids” to Jesus.  His name was David Wilkerson. He first started preaching at his country church, that he loved very much. Then he met some young people in a big city. They didn’t take good care of themselves, and they liked to fight with knives and clubs. Some of them wanted to kill him. In time, he gave up his happy church life so he could tell them about Jesus. They grew to love him.His book is called “The Cross and the Switchblade.”  He started a group called “Teen Challenge.”  This group works for Christ all over the world.

The Jews long ago often walked for hundreds of miles.  There were no cars or airplanes.  Men, women and children traveled step by step.We can grow step by step as we learn to carry His cross. Jesus said, “Come to Me, all you that are tired and carrying burdens.” We can come to Him dozens of times each day if we want to. He knows we are human. He lets His Spirit give us strength and wisdom.  James 1:2- 4 tells how early Christians suffered. We can read James 1:5, and see that God teaches people when they ask. He never condemns anyone for asking. We just have to be willing to learn and to suffer if He wants us to.

texts:
Crocodiles usually only attack if you frighten them (though sometimes a big crocodile will attack a person for food).

If a crocodile does attack you, it will drag you under the water to try to drown you. And a crocodile can hold its breath a lot longer than you can.

Your only hope is to relax and hold your breath as long as you can. The crocodile may think you have drowned, and bring you up to the surface to eat you. A crocodile cannot eat under water. When the crocodile slowly opens its mouth, you may have a chance to escape. Don’t waste it! Remember, a crocodile can close it’s mouth very fast!

Remember, also to stay away from rivers and swamps where there are crocodiles.

If you are a visitor in an area, ask the local people. They will know which places are safe, and which places are dangerous.

Suddenly, with a burst of energy that belied his seemingly lethargic state, the crocodile lunged forward, jaws agape. He snapped shut on his prey, a fish that had ventured too close to the surface. The sound echoed through the quiet waters, a stark reminder of the predator's power.

With his meal secured, the crocodile retreated back into the water, disappearing beneath the surface. He was a creature of the depths, a silent hunter, a master of his domain. The river was his realm, and he ruled it with cunning and strength.

texts:
Here’s a riddle for our day.

Out of a box comes something sweet. It is so good for the children to eat! All by itself it means nothing alone. It tells about some things no person will  own.

What is it?... or who is it? A doughnut! A zero!A zero means nothing, by itself. No one can own a zero. Tires and doughnuts and many other things are round, and may look like a zero, but a zero by itself does not mean anything, not a tire or a doughnut.

Write down a zero (0). It means nothing by itself. But, you can write a 3 just in front of the zero. It becomes something. It becomes thirty (30). Add another zero and you have 300 yards or meters. It’s long enough for an American football game. 3,000 yards is how high some small airplanes will go.

We all know about numbers and names. In a city, we may use numbers to help us know where someone lives. We might say, “He lives at 62 Gateway Lane.” These things say where he is. We will probably find him there.

Scientists and accountants use numbers to tell about greater things. What things? Think about it.

Numbers tell us about money, size, distances and time.

We have dollars, pesos, and shillings for money.
We have inches, miles, and kilometers for distance. We have minutes, hours, days, and years for time.

God led Abram outside one night and told him to count the stars he could see. The story is in Chapter 15, verse 5 of the book of Genesis in the Bible.

How any stars were there? God said this number would be the number of Abram’s family. Abram’s name became Abraham, which means father of many nations.On a clear night in a desert Abraham might have seen 5,000 stars. This number is just a small part of all the stars in our universe or all the people in Abraham’s “family” now.

But we can praise the One who made it all. We can thank Him for His numbers and size. "In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth” (Genesis 1:1) - we can’t count how long ago. We don’t have to. But we know that God is BIG and that His plan for the human race is big. We know this from His words in the Bible.

ZEROES AND LOVE: two things.

Zeros give an idea of how great God is. They tell us about His glory.

Love gives an idea of how He feels toward all us human beings.

PRAISE THE LORD. Thank Him for His glory and His love.
predicted_texts: It was said that the donut was a sign from above, a reminder to trust in a higher power, even when things seemed circular and never-ending.

Others saw the donut in the stars, a divine promise whispered among the constellations. They sought guidance from the heavens, dreaming of a future filled with abundance and blessings.

But true understanding came when they realized the donut was a symbol of emptiness, a reminder that true fulfillment lies not in what they possess, but in the void within themselves. Only by embracing the void could they find true peace and enlightenment, ascending to a higher state of being.

texts:
Once upon a time, two cats were passing through a street. Suddenly, they spotted a loaf of bread lying beneath a tree. Both cats pounced and caught the loaf at the same time. “It is mine! I saw it first," claimed one cat. The other shouted, “I pounced on it first. It belongs to me."
A large, oval-shaped loaf of bread lies on the grass.

Finally, one cat said, “I’m hungry! Let us divide it in half and take one piece each." “Good idea!" said the other cat. “But which of us will divide it?"
A monkey sitting on the branch of the tree had been watching all along. “That loaf of bread looks good. I would like it for myself," he thought.Two cats, their tails in the air, stand on either side of the loaf of bread.

He walked up to the fighting cats. “My dear friends! Can I help you?" asked the monkey. The cats told the monkey the story and asked, “Could you be the judge between us? Please divide this loaf for us?" 
Monkey quickly agreed to be the Judge. He broke the bread making one piece bigger than the other.A monkey walks on all four limbs, his curved tail raised in the air.

“Oh no! So sorry! I will take a little bite of the bigger piece to make both equal," said the monkey slyly. He took a bite from the bigger piece. But, he took a big bite. "Oh! Now it has become too small! I will just have to take a little bite from this piece now," said the clever monkey. So the Judge Monkey took another bite and then,  another!The loaf of bread is torn into two pieces, one larger than the other.

The two cats sat confused, as their bread got smaller and smaller. In minutes, the whole loaf was gone! Judge monkey said, “Wow! It was really difficult to divide that loaf! But, I must be going now." Then he jumped up the tree and was gone. “If only we had not quarreled among ourselves, we would not be hungry now," said the cats sadly.The monkey is leaving and only the back legs and tail are still visible. The two cats stand confused.

With a swift move, the monkey grabbed the bread and split it in half, offering a piece to each cat. The cats looked surprised!
The cats and the monkey, now united by their shared feast, enjoyed the bread together, proving that even the most tempting treats can be better when shared.

texts:
"All right, said Melva. "Yes, we might as well help you. We've had no luck catching fish today." The girls picked up their bilum nets and followed the hunter up the track.  After a while they came to the hunter's garden.
"Weed only the kaukau patch," said the hunter. "You can cut some sugarcane to chew as you weed. After weeding, harvest the water cress near the taro patch, and bring it to my hut." Then he left them.
When he was out of sight, a lazy girl whispered to Melva, "Why does he make us work? I don't like weeding."

But the other girls all worked hard and fast. Soon the work was done. They went to the water cress patch and harvested the fat green water cress, put it in their bilum net, and took it to the hunter's hut. They sat down outside chewing the sugarcane.
Soon the hunter came back with a big parcel of green leaves. He put it down in front of Melva and asked her to unwrap it.
"Not more water cress!" the lazy girl murmured.
Melva began to unwrap the parcel. The outside leaf, the second leaf, the third.
"Hee-e-e-cuscus! One- two- three- four- five... ten of them!" shouted Melva. Everyone jumped up and rushed to the parcel.
"We'll make a mumu," said the hunter. "Melva and your friends, peel kaukau and bananas, clean and wash the water cress, and make fire and heat the stones. I'll help you clean the cuscus."

Soon the mumu was covered. The girls sat down around the pit and told stories.  "I think mumu is ready now," said the hunter at last. "Everyday I go past you girls, and watch you trying to catch those small fish. I felt sorry for you, so I went out hunting. It was a good hunting night for me. I caught these cuscus for you. Enjoy the meal."
To everyone's surprise the lazy girl stood up and said, "Thank you. You are the kindest man."
Melva spread banana leaves on the grass near the mumu, and shared the food evenly among the seven girls and the hunter.
On the way home all the girls were lauging as they went. "No more small fish, but tasty cuscus meat! Yum! Yum!"

texts:
Then we must do the following:

1. Split one end of the dry stick.

2. Put another piece of stick in the middle to keep it open.

3. Place the kunai grass on the ground. Crush some in your hand and place it on top.

4. Place the dry stick on top of the kunai that you put on the ground.

5. Pass the bamboo strip under the stick at right angles to it so that you have one end of the strip in each hand.

6. Put your feet on each end of the stick to hold it firmly in place.

7. Start pulling the bamboo strips backwards and forwards — slowly at first, then faster and faster.

8. Soon you will see smoke rising from where the stick and bamboo strip are rubbing together. This is because the rubbing action causes heat.
Blow gently until you have a flame. Add some more grass and twigs.

Now a small fire is burning.

texts:
A number of things can lead to bones becom- ing weak.  A poor diet is one of the main causes.  Smoking, drinking alcohol, and lack of exercise are also causes of weak bones.

     We are going to look at three main ways to keep our bones strong.

One of the best ways to build strong bones is to eat lots of fruits and vegetables that are rich in calcium.  Beans, leafy greens, dried figs, and almonds are good examples.  Fish and chicken are also good sources of calcium.

Vitamin D is necessary for strong bones.  We get vitamin D from oily fish such as salmon and tuna, from duck eggs, and oranges.

     We also get vitamin D by spending time in the sun.

The third way you can build strong bones is by exercise.  The best exercises are those that require you to put weight on your bones.  Walk- ing, running, and dancing are examples of good forms of exercise.

Make an effort to always stand or sit with your back straight and your shoulders back.  Eat plenty of foods rich in calcium and vitamin D, and exercise every day.  You will not only have stronger bones, but you will also look and feel much better.

texts:
“Well, Jesus, having been the completely obedient Son of God, and knowing that all mankind falls short of obedience to God, came to earth from Heaven to accept the penalty for our sins. That was a cruel death as though he was some kind of a criminal, which He was not. After that happened He came gloriously back to life. Thus He is able to provide us with God’s forgiveness and the spiritual life that lasts forever. Believe in Jesus as your Savior and Life-giver to all who believe. This is God’s wonderful plan to do for us what we cannot possibly do for ourselves.”

“I would like that,” said Tudin. “I never thought of having a spiritual life coming from a Spiritual Father. Would He be loving and kind like my father was?”

Mikma laughed and said, “Of course, for that is what God is. God is love. Your father must have learned to be loving and kind from God, because he liked to sing that song to you. And if he meant what he sang he understood that Jesus loved him. Also that he knew that God’s Book tells about what Jesus can do for people here on earth who believe in Him.”

Tudin’s eyes gleamed with excitement but then he checked himself, saying, “Tell me more. Please tell me more!”Mikma held out both hands together like an open book, saying “In God’s Book there are seven letters Jesus sent to show His love for some groups of those who believed in Him. He encouraged them and gave them credit for the progress they had made and then he urged them to keep growing in God’s loving ways."

"What your father did in training you sounds like he taught you a bit like that. But Jesus in every letter ends with the statement, ‘Listen to what the Spirit of God is saying.’ That is so important. Spiritual life in us is God’s Spirit coming right into our hearts and guiding us in God’s way. It’s tremendous because it is God’s direct help. In one song in God’s Book it says that with the strength He gives me I can leap over a wall!”

“Leaping over a wall sounds great,” said Tudin, “but please first just show me the way into this new life with the heavenly Father that I’ve been missing without knowing I could have Him.” And at that Mikma helped him ask the heavenly Father for forgiveness for his sins and to declare his new faith in Jesus’ saving love for him.

“Now I have accepted God’s gift of eternal life through Jesus and I have called God my Father,” he exclaimed. At that the friendly stranger patted him on the back and said, “God will bless you for that! I must go now.” Shouldering his pack, he quietly slipped out of the gates.

texts:
I’ll never forget in one prayer meeting in a church when the pastor’s wife stood up to talk to us. She said, “I don’t often speak up, but the Lord is telling me to share a praise with you. My husband, as you know, has just returned from meetings in Brazil. When he flew to Brazil, you all so kindly paid for his ticket. But you did not know that when he went to buy his ticket, the price had gone up.

"He sadly took all our own money to pay the rest of the price. The only person I told about this was my sister. She then shared half of what she had for her own family, so my family would have vegetables and a little fish or meat. But she couldn’t share enough money for us to buy rice."Our rice bag only had one week’s supply of rice for me and our five children. However, during the six weeks that my husband was gone, our rice bag was never empty. When my husband got back and gave me some money for food, I went to the rice store, and they were surprised to see me. They said, “We thought you had moved away.”

I think also of a friend who had a dream about Christ and accepted Jesus as his Savior. Later he told me his whole life story. After he accepted Jesus, he married and had two daughters.

One day during a famine (a lack of food in the country), he saw a woman starting to throw her baby son into the river. He quickly stopped her and offered to adopt the baby. She agreed, and he and his wife brought this child up as their own son. They raised him to know the Lord.Our lives are made richer by our own stories but also by the stories of other people. I still keep in touch with a woman in Texas, who I met when I was a young pastor one summer. There in Texas is where I held a revival meeting outside of town in a tent, and we baptized people in a nearby pond.

Here is an example of a teacher using a simple way to explain how God protects us. While teaching about God’s protection, she would open her Bible wide, put in a sheet of folded paper, then close the Bible tight. The paper was safe inside. The students understood that God protects us. They opened their hearts to Jesus. I was happy to hear this story and to share it with other people.

Yes, let’s share the stories of the many ways God has blessed us, so the future generations will know and understand His love.

texts:
Teacher: Thank you, Tevita. Where are they?
Annie: (whispering): In the corn garden!

Teacher: Thank you, Annie.

- They look out the window. -

Annie: Look! There’s smoke!

Tevita: It’s coming from the kunai!

David: Mmmm! It’s almost cooked.

Harold: I'm going to eat lots!

Teacher (to children): Wait here!

- She marches of to the kunai patch. -

“Where did you boys get this corn?”

Harold: From the Eagles‘ garden.

Teacher: From the Eagles‘ garden?

Myra: Hey! That is our corn!

Teacher: Well, thank you boys for making a fire for the Eagles. Thank you for harvesting their corn and cooking it for them. Now go and wait in the line.

- The children all laugh. -

Children: Ha! Ha! No corn for you!

Teacher (calling): Eagles, Eagles, come and eat your corn,

Myra: Come on girls, let‘s go.

- They sit around the fire. -

Myra: Mmmm! It’s delicious.

Annie: Corn! My favourite.

Tevita: It’s the best corn I‘ve ever tasted.
predicted_texts: The teacher pointed towards the window, her expression stern. "Who started that fire?" she demanded, her eyes scanning the line of students. A plume of smoke billowed in the distance, a clear sign of mischief gone awry.

Outside, the teacher confronted three students huddled around a small, smoldering fire. Charred sticks lay scattered around the flames, evidence of their playful arson. "Explain yourselves," she said, her voice laced with disappointment.

The students looked down, shamefaced. They had been roasting corn, a harmless activity that had quickly spiraled out of control. "We didn't mean for it to get so big," one of them mumbled, offering a half-eaten cob as a peace offering.
